source.body: The culture medium should become totally opaque in the morning.

Decant 12 x
LB broth medium into 12 x
conical flasks.

source.description:
Supplement each flask/litre with
of

Mix and add
–
of the
culture into each flask.

source.title: Set up cells and induce expression

source.description:
Incubate for
at
, using an Infors Shaker-Incubator set at

source.title: Set up cells and induce expression

source.description:
Sample two or three of the expressions by removing
medium and comparing the optical density at 600 nm with fresh LB medium, using a WPA cell densitometer or a spectrometer.

source.title: Set up cells and induce expression

source.description:
When the OD600 has reached 0.7-0.9, change the temperature setting of the Infors incubator to
and incubate the cells for at least another
, all the while shaking at

When the flasks have cooled down to
or lower, induce Rab8A expression by supplementing the medium with

of a

of cell collection buffer and chill

Decant the content of the
conical flasks into
Beckman centrifuge pots, close the pots with their screwcap lids and sediment the cells by centrifugation for
at
at

source.title: Collection of cells and preparation of lysate

source.description: Collect and open the pots and carefully decant the spent supernatant medium back into the flasks.

source.body: The flasks can now be sent for cleaning and autoclaving. The cell sediment in the pots is expected to have a volume of – .

source.title: Collection of cells and preparation of lysate

source.description:
Add
of cold cell collection buffer to the sediment.

Transfer the
pots to the Infors incubator and set the temperature to
and the rotation to

, after which time the cell sediment should have completely resuspended.

source.title: Collection of cells and preparation of lysate

source.description:
Pool all suspensions into one of the 12 pots using a
pipette and a good pipettor. If any of the sediments has not well resuspended, pipette up and down close to the bottom of the pots.

source.title: Collection of cells and preparation of lysate

source.description:
For Rab8A and other Rab proteins is it very useful at this stage to supplement the NaCl concentration to
and add glycerol to 5% (by vol) final concentration.

source.body: It is important to add the NaCl and glycerol after the resuspension step and not before as this interferes with the resuspension.

source.title: Collection of cells and preparation of lysate

source.description:
Once the NaCl and glycerol has been mixed in,
samples are aliquoted into
centrifuge vials and freeze them in liquid nitrogen for at least
.

source.body: The vials can be stored at for at least 4 weeks. The freezing and subsequent thawing step breaks up the cells and improves yield.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description: Slowly thaw the vials with the cell suspension in cold water.

source.body: We have verified that it is OK to leave the tubes to thaw samples by leaving these at .

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
After thawing chill suspension on ice and then sonicate, using a probe sonicator (Cell disruptor). Settings: 6-8 pulses of
with 15 sec pauses. Set the amplitude to 50%.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
The lysate will warm up slightly, but make sure it does not warm up over
and keep samples cool by swirling on ice.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
Transfer the sonicated suspension into
Beckman centrifuge vials and sediment the insoluble
material by centrifugation for
at
an
using a 25.50 or a 30.50 rotor in a Beckman Avanti centrifuge.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
Recover the supernatant by carefully decanting it into a
Corning PP conical centrifuge tube.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
During the centrifugation step equilibrate
Ni-agarose (
of a 50% slurry, sufficient for a 12 L expression) by washing it three times with Milli Q water and once with cell collection buffer.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
Add a 50% slurry of the washed Ni-agarose in collection buffer to the lysate and incubate the mix on a Roller Mixer for
in a cold room set at
.

source.body: Avoid excessive agitation and especially formation of foam.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description: In the meanwhile, prepare Ni-wash buffer. Carefully sediment the Niagarose by centrifugation using a Beckman J6 with a 4.2 rotor and suitable adaptors.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
Centrifuge at
for
at
.

source.body: Avoid higher centrifugation speeds as the PP conical centrifuge vessels are structurally weak.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
Remove the lid and carefully decant the supernatant containing the depleted lysate using a
pipette, being careful not to disturb the Ni-agarose.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
Add
of Ni-wash buffer.

source.description:
Prepare a
pipette tip by removing 5 mm-7 mm from the pointed end using scissors.

source.body: This allows it to be used to facilely resuspend the agarose.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
Resuspend the Ni-agarose using a P1000 with such a modified blue tip and aliquot the Ni-agarose into a
centrifuge vial.

source.description:
Wash out any remaining agarose from the large vial with
of Ni-wash buffer and pool with the first
batch to maximise recovery.

source.description:
Fill the
vial to the top with Ni-wash buffer, mix well and sediment resin by centrifugation at
for
using an Eppendorf 5810 R centrifuge.

source.description: Remove the Ni-wash buffer with a thin vacuum line and replace with fresh Ni-wash buffer.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description: Repeat this step 5 times in total to thoroughly wash the resin.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description: Remove all Ni-wash buffer without disturbing the agarose bed.

source.description:
Resuspend the Ni-agarose into
wash buffer, transfer into a BIORAD Econopac column and let the buffer run out.

source.description:
Add
of Ni-elution buffer and let the void of the bed run out. Then elute the protein with
Nielution buffer into a
centrifuge vial.

source.body: This should provide of protein solution of - ( – total protein).

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
Add
Thrombin solution (1000 Units per ml) and dialyse
against
of Rab8A dialysis
buffer using Thermo-Fisher Snake Skin 3500 MWCO.

source.title: Preparation of cell lysate and pulldown of His-Rab8A on Ni-agarose

source.description:
The next day recover the protein into a
vial.

source.body: The dialysis step is important, as high imidazole concentrations inhibit the subsequent kinase reaction. The higher glycerol concentration during dialysis will reduce the volume of the sample by up to 20%. We keep the sample volume small to avoid unnecessary protein concentration steps before the subsequent size exclusion.

source.title: Phosphorylation

source.description:
Take
of Rab8A as an unphosphorylated control. Add
His-MST3 (2.3 ml 3.5mg/ml) to the Rab8A protein and mix well.

source.title: Phosphorylation

source.description:
Add
of
Tris
to buffer to ATP solution.

source.title: Phosphorylation

source.description:
Add
MgCl2 and
ATP and mix well but gently.

source.title: Phosphorylation

source.description:
Leave with an incubator at
.

source.title: Phosphorylation

source.description:
Next day prepare a
Ni-agarose bed and capture the His-tagged MST3 by letting the sample run through the bed.

source.title: Further purification by Size Exclusion Chromatography

source.description:
Equilibrate a Superdex 75 XK 26/60 format in 3 column volumes of SEC buffer at a flowrate of
using an Akta Pure.

source.body: The untagged Rab8A is a mix of aggregated pRab8A, MST3 (Mw 51.8 kDa), Thrombin (native Mw 37 kDa) and monomeric pRab8A 1-181 (Mw 22.9 kDa). Size Exclusion Chromatography using a Superdex 75 XK 26/60 column offers a simple and powerful solution for isolation of monomeric pRab8A 1-181. The species are separated so well, that we have somewhat overloaded the column and apply a sample representing 4% of the column volume instead of the recommended 1%.

source.title: Further purification by Size Exclusion Chromatography

source.description:
Apply the sample
-
(typical concentration of
-
) to the Gel filtration at a flowrate of
and collect
fractions between
to
.

source.title: Further purification by Size Exclusion Chromatography

source.description:
Elute the monomeric pRab8A as a 36 ml peak from
to
with the apex at around
.

source.title: Further purification by Size Exclusion Chromatography

source.description: Pool the fractions containing the core of the pRab8A peak into one vial. A typical elution chromatogram is shown on Figure 1.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho  species

source.description: In order to separate the phospho species from each other and from the remaining unphosphorylated protein, employ cation exchange chromatography using a Source 15 S column.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho  species

source.description:
To this end, pack an empty HR10/10 or GL 10/100 column with
Source 15 S resin and use vacuum suction to obtain a homogenous well packed resin bed.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho  species

source.description: Ion exchange chromatography is a concentrating method, hence the load volume is not critical. Therefore, dilute aliquots of the monomeric Rab8A sample into the Low Salt buffer to reduce the ionic strength sufficiently for the protein to bind.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho  species

source.description: In contrast, dialysing highly concentrated Rab8A into the Low Salt Buffer leads to substantial protein aggregation and precipitation.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho  species

source.description: Equilibrate the Source 15 S HR10/10 with the IEX- buffers using an Akta Pure or Purifier.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho  species

source.description: Dilute the pRab8A protein isolated from the gel filtration step tenfold into the IEX-LowSalt buffer.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho  species

source.description:
Apply aliquots equivalent to 5-6mg to the S-column at a flowrate of
.

source.title: Chromatography on a Source 15 S HR10/10 column to separate phospho  species

source.description:
Develop the column at the same flow rate with a shallow
gradient to 30% IEX-High Salt buffer collecting
fractions.

source.body: Generally, up to four peaks are resolved see Figure 2. Our QC analysis indicates that the peaks C and D eluting between 6 and 8 mS/cm both represent Thr72 monophosphorylated Rab8A.

source.title: Quality control

source.description:
Separate
of the protein on a 4% - 20% Tris v with Instant Blue (Figure 3).

source.body: The protein should be >95% homogeneous.

source.title: Quality control

source.description:
Separate a
of pRab8A[1-181] and
of unphosphorylated Rab8A (1-181) on a 12% Phos-tag SDS-Polyacrylamid gel that separates phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated Rab proteins, run as described previously (Ito et al. 2016) (Figure 4).

source.body: The migration of the phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated pRab8A proteins can clearly be distinguished.

source.title: Quality control

source.description:
Immunoblot analysis of pRab8A[1-181] and dephosphorylated Rab8A[1-181] undertaken as described previously
(dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.bsgrnbv6) using Rab8A pThr72 and total antibodies (Figure 5). This will reveal that the pRab8A protein is specifically phosphorylated at Thr72.

source.title: Quality control

source.description:
Incubate
pRab8A[1-181] ±
o PPM1H (can be ordered from MRCPPU Reagents and Services, DU62835) in the presence of
MgCl2 for
at
prior to running a Phostag gel.

source.body: Recombinant PPM1H phosphatase should quantitatively dephosphorylate pThr72 phosphorylated Rab8A.

source.title: Quality control

source.description:
The pRab8A[1-181] can also be analysed by Mass Spectrometry after trypsin digestion. The tryptic peptide
encompassing Thr72 should only be mainly present in the phosphorylated form and levels of the non-phosphorylated peptide should be very low to undetectable.

description: A subset of small GTPases of the Rab family including Rab8A (Uniprot: P61006) have been identified as substrates of the Leucine Rich Repeat Kinase 2 (LRRK2; Uniprot Q5S007)) and the Protein Phosphatase PPM1H (Uniprot Q9ULR3) (Steger et al., 2016; Berndsen et al., 2019). In order to perform detailed study of Rab phosphorylation and dephosphorylation, as well as produce phosphorylation site-specific antibodies, and to carry out drug discovery screens, it is necessary to produce hundreds of milligrams of pure, stoichiometrically phosphorylated Rab8A protein. The full-length sequence of Rab8A is prone to aggregation and precipitation when expressed in bacteria. Therefore, a shorter fragment, spanning residues 1-181 is more useful for large scale expression. Here we describe in detail the method we use to produce milligram quantities of stoichiometrically Thr72 phosphorylated Rab8A[1-181]. We employ the MST3 kinase to phosphorylate Rab8A at Thr72, as this kinase is much easier and less expensive to produce or purchase than LRRK2 (Berndsen et al., 2019, Vieweg et al. 2020).
